On Tue, Feb 2, 2010 at 9:32 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> On Mon=
, Feb 1, 2010 at 1:07 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
> <berin.loritsch@...> =
wrote:
>> Some of the annotations are pretty well understood and map direct=
ly to
>> JUnit 3 concepts, so I'll just keep them here for completeness:
>>=

>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @Test - run this method as a test
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @Ignor=
e - do not run this test for now
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @Before - set up data for=
 the next test
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @After - tear down data for the next test
>=
> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @BeforeClass - set up supporting classes for this suite of =
tests
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @AfterClass - tear down supporting classes for this =
suite of
>> tests
>>
>> After that is a whole bunch of annotations that are=
 quite new to me and
>> I'm trying to understand when, where, and how to us=
e them:
>>
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @Rule - Mark a test attribute that extends Meth=
odRule to affect
>> the test outcome (more advanced verifications)
>> * =A0=
 =A0 =A0 @Category - Mark tests or test classes as belonging to a
>> catego=
ry, which is used with specific test suites. =A0Not sure how this
>> works =
when you are invoking the tests through a build system. =A0For
>> example, =
turn off slow tests until we do integration etc. =A0At least it
>> is marke=
d.
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @RunWith(Runner.class) - Run a test suite with a partic=
ular
>> runner. =A0Enables other things like theories to work
>>
>> Theorie=
s: thanks for the blog entry, it helps. =A0Are these meant to
>> verify an =
algorithm with several datapoints? =A0If not, what other uses
>> were they =
designed for?
>
> The short and long version are here:
>
> http://shareande=
njoy.saff.net/2006/12/new-paper-practice-of-theories.html
>
>> * =A0 =A0 =
=A0 @DataPoint - used with theories, marks a test attribute as data
>> to p=
ass in to parameterized tests
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @DataPoints - used with theo=
ries, marks a test attribute that is
>> a collection as data to pass in to =
parameterized tests? =A0Pure guess
>> here.
>
> Right.
>
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @=
ParametersSuppliedBy(ParameterSupplier.class) - used with
>> theories, maps=
 datapoints to the theory tests? =A0Pure guess here.
>
> http://docs.codeha=
us.org/display/GROOVY/Using+Popper+with+Groovy has a
> good example of usin=
g ParametersSuppliedBy to introduce per-parameters
> value ranges. =A0This =
feature hasn't proven to get much traction.
>
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @Theory - ma=
rks a parameterized test that is executed several
>> times to include all a=
pplicable combinations of datapoints
>> * =A0 =A0 =A0 @TestedOn - not sure =
about its applicability.
>
> I'm not even sure what that is.

Oh, right, it=
's a sample theory parameter supplier that gives explicit
parameter values.=
  I don't believe it's ever been used outside of
examples.

   David Saff

=
>
>>
>> Parameterized: run tests with a list of parameters. =A0The List of
=
>> parameters is specified by the @Parameters method.
>>
>> Suites: run a s=
uite of tests. =A0The set of classes is marked by
>> @SuiteClasses.
